issues.text: whether, under the relevant statutory provisions, an accused who was sentenced to transportation for life, could legally be imprisoned in one of the jails in India and if so, what was the term for which he could be so imprisoned.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that falls to be decided is whether, under the relevant statutory provisions, an accused who was sentenced to transportation for life, could legally be imprisoned in one of the jails in India and if so, what was the term for which he could be so imprisoned. We shall briefly notice the relevant provisions of the Indian Penal Code before it was amended by the Code of Criminal Procedure Amendment Act XXVI of 1955.

issues.text: whether the petitioner, who was sentenced to transportation, could be dealt with legally as if he were a person sentenced to rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: On that basis, a question arises whether the petitioner, who was sentenced to transportation, could be dealt with legally as if he were a person sentenced to rigorous imprisonment. This question was raised before the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor . After considering the history of the sentence of transportation, the relevant provisions of the Indian Penal Code, the Code of Criminal Procedure and the Prisons Act, the Privy Council came to the conclusion that the said provisions made it plain that when a sentence of transportation had been passed it was no longer necessarily a sentence of transportation beyond the seas.

issues.text: whether there is any provision of law whereunder a sentence for life imprisonment, without any formal remission by appropriate Government, can be automatically treated as one for a definite period.

anchor.surface_text: If so, the next question is whether there is any provision of law whereunder a sentence for life imprisonment, without any formal remission by appropriate Government, can be automatically treated as one for a definite period. No such provision is found in the Indian Penal Code, Code of Criminal Procedure or the Prisons Act.

issues.text: whether Section 57 of the Indian Penal Code deems transportation for life to be equivalent to twenty years imprisonment for all purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 57 of the Indian Penal Code has no real bearing on the question raised before us. For calculating fractions of terms of punishment the section provides that transportation for life shall be regarded as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years. It does not say that transportation for life shall be deemed to be transportation for twenty years for all purposes nor does the amended section which substitutes the words imprisonment for life for transportation for life enable the drawing of any such all-embracing fiction.

issues.text: whether the Bombay rules governing the remission system substituted a definite period for life imprisonment and, therefore, if the aggregate of the term actually served exceeds the said period, the person would be entitled to be released.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the Bombay rules governing the remission system substituted a definite period for life imprisonment and, therefore, if the aggregate of the term actually served exceeds the said period, the person would be entitled to be released. To appreciate this contention the relevant Bombay rules may be read.

issues.text: whether the remissions earned entitle the petitioner to be released without orders under Section 401, Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Person sentenced to transportation for life before 1955 amendment can be dealt with as sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for life under s.53A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: in view of s. 53A of the Indian Penal Code which has been added by Act XXVI of 1955. Section 53A of the said Code reads In every case in which a sentence of transportation for a term has been passed before the commencement of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, 1954, the offender shall be dealt with in the same manner as if sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for the same term.

arguments.claim: Sentence of transportation for life can legally be undergone by rigorous imprisonment in Indian jail.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that falls to be decided is whether, under the relevant statutory provisions, an accused who was sentenced to transportation for life, could legally be imprisoned in one of the jails in India and if so, what was the term for which he could be so imprisoned. We shall briefly notice the relevant provisions of the Indian Penal Code before it was amended by the Code of Criminal Procedure Amendment Act XXVI of 1955.

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor held transportation sentence no longer necessarily beyond seas; can be served in Indian jails as rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: This question was raised before the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor. After considering the history of the sentence of transportation, the relevant provisions of the Indian Penal Code, the Code of Criminal Procedure and the Prisons Act, the Privy Council came to the conclusion that the said provisions made it plain that when a sentence of transportation had been passed it was no longer necessarily a sentence of transportation beyond the seas.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anysidering the history of the sentence of transportation, the relevant provisions of the Indian Pen

arguments.court_reasoning: Agree with weighty authority; reinforced by s.53A IPC.

arguments.claim: No provision automatically treats life sentence as definite period without formal remission by government.

anchor.surface_text: If so, the next question is whether there is any provision of law whereunder a sentence for life imprisonment, without any formal remission by appropriate Government, can be automatically treated as one for a definite period. No such provision is found in the Indian Penal Code, Code of Criminal Procedure or the Prisons Act.

arguments.claim: S.57 IPC equates life to 20 years only for calculating fractions of punishment, not for all purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 57 of the Indian Penal Code has no real bearing on the question raised before us. For calculating fractions of terms of punishment the section provides that transportation for life shall be regarded as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years. It does not say that transportation for life shall be deemed to be transportation for twenty years for all purposes nor does the amended section which substitutes the words imprisonment for life for transportation for life enable the drawing of any such all-embracing fiction.

arguments.claim: Bombay prison rules do not substitute definite period for life sentence or confer automatic right to release on earning remissions.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the Bombay rules governing the remission system substituted a definite period for life imprisonment and, therefore, if the aggregate of the term actually served exceeds the said period, the person would be entitled to be released. To appreciate this contention the relevant Bombay rules may be read.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: heir Lordships are number to be taken as meaning that a life sentence must and in all cases be treated as one of number more than twenty years, or tha

arguments.court_reasoning: Rules have statutory force but only regulate prisons/treatment; equation in r.1419(c) only for remission system ('ordinarily'); r.1447(2) requires govt order; no power to remit sentences.

arguments.claim: Prison rules' equation of life to 15 years actual imprisonment is only for remission system purpose, not statutory for all purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1419. (c) A sentence of transportation for life shall ordinarily be taken as 15 Years actual imprisonment. ... The rule cannot be construed as a statutory equation of 15 years actual imprisonment for transportation for life. The equation is only for a particular purpose, namely, for the purpose of remission system and not for all purposes. The word ordinarily in the rule also supports the said construction.

arguments.claim: No release without government orders under s.401 CrPC even after earning remissions entitling to release per rules.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 934. In all cases of premature releases, orders under Section 401, Criminal Procedure Code, will have to be issued by Government before the prisoners can actually be released from Jail. Rule 937. (c) When a life convict ... has earned such remission as would entitle him to release but for the provisions of this rule, the Superintendent shall report accordingly to the State Government ...

arguments.claim: Completion of term per remissions does not ipso facto confer right to release; requires govt report/orders.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1447. (2) Notwithstanding anything contained in rule 1419 no prisoner who has been sentenced to transportation for life ... shall be released on completion of his term of transportation or imprisonment ... unless ... orders of Government have been received thereon ... This also indicates that the period of 15 years actual imprisonment specified in the rule is only for the purpose of calculating the remission and that the completion of the term on that basis does not ipso facto confer any right upon the prisoner to release.

arguments.claim: Prisons Act rules do not confer power to commute/remit sentences; only regulate prisons and good conduct rewards.

anchor.surface_text: It is common case that the said rules were made under the Prisons Act, 1894, and that they have statutory force. But the Prisons Act does not confer on any authority a power to commute or remit sentences it provides only for the regulation of prisons and for the treatment of prisoners confined therein. Section 59 of the Prisons Act confers a power on the State Government to make rules, inter alia, for rewards for good conduct.

arguments.claim: Life sentence prima facie for whole natural life unless commuted/remitted.

anchor.surface_text: A sentence of transportation for life or imprisonment for life must prima facie be treated as transportation or imprisonment for the whole of the remaining period of the convicted persons natural life.

arguments.claim: Government has exclusive power to remit; court cannot assume unreasonable exercise.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution as well as the Code of Criminal Procedure confer the power to remit a sentence on the executive Government and it is in its exclusive province. We cannot assume that the appropriate Government will not exercise its jurisdiction in a reasonable manner.

arguments.claim: Petitioner at mercy of government which might not remit out of spite, depriving fruits of good conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner made an impassioned appeal to us that if such a construction be accepted, he would be at the mercy of the appropriate Government and that the said Government, out of spite, might not remit the balance of his sentence, with the result that he would be deprived of the fruits of remissions earned by him for sustained good conduct, useful service and even donation of blood.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s of remissions earned by him for sustained good companyduct, useful service and even donation of blood. The Constitution as well as the Code of Crimi

arguments.court_reasoning: Power exclusively with executive; no assumption of unreasonable exercise.

holdings.text: A person sentenced to transportation for life before the 1955 amendment can legally be dealt with as sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for life in an Indian jail.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this weighty authority with which we agree, it is not necessary to consider the relevant provisions, particularly in view of s. 53A of the Indian Penal Code which has been added by Act XXVI of 1955. Section 53A of the said Code reads  1  In every case in which a sentence of transportation for a term has been passed before the commencement of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, 1954, the offender shall be dealt with in the same manner as if sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for the same term.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council precedent in Pandit Kishori Lal and applies s.53A IPC post-1955 amendment substituting transportation with rigorous imprisonment.

holdings.text: There is no provision of law under which a sentence for life imprisonment can be automatically treated as one for a definite period without formal remission by the appropriate Government.

anchor.surface_text: If so, the next question is whether there is any provision of law whereunder a sentence for life imprisonment, without any formal remission by appropriate Government, can be automatically treated as one for a definite period. No such provision is found in the Indian Penal Code, Code of Criminal Procedure or the Prisons Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of IPC, CrPC, Prisons Act reveals no automatic conversion to definite term.

holdings.text: Section 57 IPC equates transportation for life to 20 years imprisonment only for calculating fractions of terms of punishment, not for all purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 57 of the Indian Penal Code has no real bearing on the question raised before us. For calculating fractions of terms of punishment the section provides that transportation for life shall be regarded as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years. It does not say that transportation for life shall be deemed to be transportation for twenty years for all purposes nor does the amended section which substitutes the words imprisonment for life for transportation for life enable the drawing of any such all-embracing fiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual interpretation limits s.57 to fractions; distinguishes from broader equivalence; notes Privy Council reservation.

holdings.text: A sentence of transportation for life or imprisonment for life must prima facie be treated as for the whole of the remaining period of the convicted person's natural life.

anchor.surface_text: A sentence of transportation for life or imprisonment for life must prima facie be treated as transportation or imprisonment for the whole of the remaining period of the convicted persons natural life.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established doctrine from precedents; no statutory override without commutation/remission.

holdings.text: Bombay prison rules do not substitute a definite period for life imprisonment or confer an indefeasible right to release upon earning remissions exceeding that period.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 934. In all cases of premature releases, orders under Section 401, Criminal Procedure Code, will have to be issued by Government before the prisoners can actually be released from Jail. ... The completion of the term on that basis does not ipso facto confer any right upon the prisoner to release.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules under Prisons Act regulate treatment/rewards, not remission power; r.1419(c) equation 'ordinarily' only for remission calculation; r.934,937(c),1447(2) require s.401 CrPC orders; no automatic release.

holdings.text: Rule 1419(c) equating transportation for life to 15 years actual imprisonment is only for the purpose of the remission system, not a statutory equation for all purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1419. (c) A sentence of transportation for life shall ordinarily be taken as 15 Years actual imprisonment. ... The rule cannot be construed as a statutory equation of 15 years actual imprisonment for transportation for life. The equation is only for a particular purpose, namely, for the purpose of remission system and not for all purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'ordinarily' limits scope; r.1447(2) non-obstante clause subordinates to govt orders.

holdings.text: Earned remissions do not entitle a life convict to release without orders under s.401 CrPC from the appropriate Government.

precedents.citation: Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor 1 . After considering the history of the sentence of transportation, the relevant provisions of the Indian Penal Code, the Code of Criminal Procedure and the Prisons Act, the Privy Council came to the conclusion that the said provisions made it plain that when a sentence of transportation had been passed it was no longer necessarily a sentence of transportation beyond the seas. It was observed at p. 9 thus But at the present day transportation is in truth but a name given in India to a sentence for life and, in a few special cases, for a lesser period, just as in England the term imprisonment is applied to all sentences which do number exceed two years and penal servitude to those of three years and upwards So, in India, a prisoner sentenced to transportation may be sent to the Andamans or may be kept in one of the jails in India appointed for transportation prisoners, where he will be dealt with in the same manner as a prisoner sentenced to rigorous imprisonment.

precedents.case_name: Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: a sentence of transportation for life in India is effectively a sentence of life imprisonment to be served in jails in India as rigorous imprisonment, not necessarily transportation beyond the seas
precedents.cited_holding: But at the present day transportation is in truth but a name given in India to a sentence for life and, in a few special cases, for a lesser period, just as in England the term imprisonment is applied to all sentences which do number exceed two years and penal servitude to those of three years and upwards So, in India, a prisoner sentenced to transportation may be sent to the Andamans or may be kept in one of the jails in India appointed for transportation prisoners, where he will be dealt with in the same manner as a prisoner sentenced to rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: 1   1944  L.R. 72 I.A. I , Whatever justification there might have been for the contention that a person sentenced to transportation could not be legally made to undergo rigorous imprisonment in a jail in India except temporarily till he was so transported, subsequent to the said amendment there is none.

precedents.case_name: Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: historical context supporting treatment of transportation as imprisonment in India

anchor.surface_text: the Government of India stated before the Judicial Committee in the case cited supra that, having regard to s. 57 of the Indian Penal Code, 20 years imprisonment was equivalent to a sentence of transportation for life, the Judicial Committee did not express its final opinion on that question.

precedents.case_name: Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: Government view that s.57 makes transportation for life equivalent to 20 years, but JC did not decide

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee observed in that case thus at p. 10 Assuming that the sentence is to be regarded as one of twenty years, and subject to remission for good conduct, he had not earned remission sufficient to entitle him to discharge at the time of his application, and it was therefore rightly dismissed, but in saying this, their Lordships are not to be taken as meaning that a life sentence must and in all cases be treated as one of not more than twenty years, or that the convict is necessarily entitled to remission.

precedents.case_name: Pandit Kishori Lal v. King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: a life sentence is not necessarily to be treated as 20 years imprisonment for all purposes, and convict not necessarily entitled to remission to reduce it to 20 years
precedents.cited_holding: their Lordships are not to be taken as meaning that a life sentence must and in all cases be treated as one of not more than twenty years, or that the convict is necessarily entitled to remission.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this weighty authority with which we agree, it is not necessary to consider the relevant provisions, particularly in view of s. 53A of the Indian Penal Code which has been added by Act XXVI of 1955. Section 53A of the said Code reads  1  In every case in which a sentence of transportation for a term has been passed before the commencement of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, 1954, the offender shall be dealt with in the same manner as if sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for the same term.

edges.explanation: The holding addresses the issue by affirming that transportation sentences can be treated as rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: If so, the next question is whether there is any provision of law whereunder a sentence for life imprisonment, without any formal remission by appropriate Government, can be automatically treated as one for a definite period. No such provision is found in the Indian Penal Code, Code of Criminal Procedure or the Prisons Act.
For the foregoing reasons we hold that the petitioner is under legal detention and the petition for habeas companypus is number maintainable.

edges.explanation: Holding grounds the concept by interpreting IPC s.57 as limited to fractions for calculating punishment
The holding states that Section 57 equates life to 20 years only for fractions, directly addressing the issue of whether it is for all purposes

anchor.surface_text: Section 57 of the Indian Penal Code has no real bearing on the question raised before us. For calculating fractions of terms of punishment the section provides that transportation for life shall be regarded as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years. It does not say that transportation for life shall be deemed to be transportation for twenty years for all purposes nor does the amended section which substitutes the words imprisonment for life for transportation for life enable the drawing of any such all-embracing fiction.
For the foregoing reasons we hold that the petitioner is under legal detention and the petition for habeas companypus is number maintainable.
For the foregoing reasons we hold that the petitioner is under legal detention and the petition for habeas companypus is number maintainable.
